value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">18</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">distance he sees them 
            <choice>
              <sic>pictriallly</sic>
              <corr>pictorally</corr>
            </choice>; grouped, like the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>figur s</sic>
              <corr>figures</corr>
            </choice> in a fresco,with the flowers growing at their feet,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">behind them marble pillars, trees with bright birds, and</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the libbard and the lion 
            <choice>
              <sic>couching</sic>
              <corr>couchant</corr>
            </choice> or 
            <choice>
              <sic>rampamt</sic>
              <corr>rampant</corr>
            </choice>. There is no</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">tension; no direction but always movement, as the metre</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">flings its curve of sound that, like a wave, breaks always</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">on the same 
            <choice>
              <sic>pace</sic>
              <corr>place</corr>
            </choice>. Folded in this 
            <choice>
              <sic>intation</sic>
              <corr>incantation</corr>
            </choice> we 
            <choice>
              <sic>drwose</sic>
              <corr>drowse</corr>
            </choice>and</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">sleep yet always start awake. <add hand="ms" place="inline">For the T [illeg.] is illuminated.</add></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><add hand="ms" place="inline"><</add>Still there is something anonymous about <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-espe" key="Spenser, Edmund">Spenser</rs>.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He cannot confine emotions within one person.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He must externalise and symbolise.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del hand="ms">But</del> Spenser standing on the threshold of the great room</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">is half in 
            <choice>
              <sic>shdow</sic>
              <corr>shadow</corr>
            </choice>, half in light. He is still anonymous</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in that he cannot confine emotions within one person.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He must symbolise; exteriorise. If a man is jealous, he 
            <choice>
              <sic>canno</sic>
              <corr>cannot</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">show it save by making a symbol of jealousy. He must</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>Jealusy</sic>
              <corr>Jealousy</corr>
            </choice> becomes     The feelings of men and women must be</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>symblised</sic>
              <corr>symbolised</corr>
            </choice> and given a body outside 
            <choice>
              <sic>th ir</sic>
              <corr>their</corr>
            </choice> own. He ignores</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>hims lf</sic>
              <corr>himself</corr>
            </choice>, the individual. Yet at the same time, forces are at</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">work that make him conscious of himself, the man who is</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">separate from the 
            <choice>
              <sic>audeince</sic>
              <corr>audience</corr>
            </choice>, who is giving the 
            <choice>
              <sic>wolrd</sic>
              <corr>world</corr>
            </choice> something</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of himself, 
            <choice>
              <sic>whois</sic>
              <corr>who is</corr>
            </choice> conscious of the worlds 
            <choice>
              <sic>scron</sic>
              <corr>scorn</corr>
            </choice> and neglect</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of what he gives. He is aware of his art as <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-gcha" key="Chaucer, Geoffrey">Chaucer</rs> was</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">not, nor <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-wlan" key="Langland, William">Langland</rs>, nor <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-tmal" key="Malory, Thomas">
            <choice>
              <sic>Malry</sic>
              <corr>Malory</corr>
            </choice></rs>. His is no longer a wandering</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">voice, but the voice of a man practising an art, and</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">asking for recognition.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Had the poet remained in the great room, 
            <choice>
              <sic>profferig</sic>
              <corr>proffering</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">his book to the little group of readers, English poetry</l>
